PURPOSE
The purpose of this policy is to establish requirements for contingency planning for PeaceHealth information systems to aid in protecting the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of PeaceHealth's information systems.
DEFINITIONS
•
Information system: A discrete set of information resources organized for the collection, processing, maintenance, use, sharing, dissemination, or disposition of information.
•
Maximum tolerable downtime (MTD): The MTD represents the total amount of time the system owner/authorizing official is willing to accept for a mission/business process outage or disruption and includes all impact considerations.
•
Recovery point objective (RPO): The point in time, prior to a disruption or system outage, to which mission/business process data can be recovered (given the most recent backup copy of the data) after an outage.
•
Recovery time objective (RTO): The maximum amount of time that a system resource can remain unavailable before there is an unacceptable impact on other system resources, supported mission/business processes, and the MTD.
POLICY
It is the policy of PeaceHealth that the following requirements are implemented to support contingency planning for PeaceHealth information systems:
1.
PeaceHealth develops and maintains a contingency plan for a disruption, compromise, or failure of the information system that has the following attributes:
a.
The plan identifies mission-critical functions and associated contingency requirements;
b.
The plan establishes recovery point objectives (RPO), recovery time objectives (RTO), and maximum tolerable downtime (MTD);
c.
The plan lists roles and responsibilities, assigns individuals to those roles and responsibilities, and lists the contact information for those individuals;
d.
The plan addresses maintaining mission-critical systems and functions; and
e.
The plan addresses full information system restoration while maintaining the security safeguards that were originally implemented.
2.
PeaceHealth ensures that the contingency plan is reviewed and approved by executive leadership, including Technology Solutions Partners (TSP) and Information Security leadership, prior to plan implementation.
3.
PeaceHealth provides training to users that is consistent with the user's responsibilities during activation of the contingency plan.
4.
PeaceHealth tests the contingency plan at least annually and updates the plan if testing finds the plan to be insufficient to meet business objectives.
5.
PeaceHealth establishes an alternate storage site that has the following characteristics:
a.
The site accommodates the storage and retrieval of information system backups as specified in the PeaceHealth Contingency Plan;
b.
The site provides information security safeguards that are equivalent to those of the primary site; and
c.
The alternate site is geographically distinct from the primary site.
6.
PeaceHealth establishes an alternate processing site that has the following characteristics:
a.
The site meets requirements as specified in the PeaceHealth Contingency Plan for the resumption of essential business functions when the primary site becomes unavailable;
b.
The site provides information security safeguards that are equivalent to those of the primary site; and
c.
The alternate site is geographically distinct from the primary site.
7.
PeaceHealth establishes alternate telecommunications services to ensure that mission-critical business functions that are reliant upon telecommunications meet PeaceHealth continuity requirements as specified in the PeaceHealth Contingency Plan.
8.
PeaceHealth does the following regarding information system backups:
a.
Creates and maintains retrievable exact copies of electronic protected health information (ePHI);
b.
Creates and maintains backups of user-level information, system-level information, and information system documentation; and
c.
Protects the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of backup information at all storage locations.
9.
PeaceHealth provides for the recovery and return to normal operation of the information system after a disruption, compromise, or failure.
COMPLIANCE
Individuals included in the scope of this policy are required to comply with the policy and all associated policies and procedures. Violations are subject to removal of access and/or corrective action, up to and including termination of employment or other business relationship with PeaceHealth. Any deviations from security policy must be communicated to Information Security immediately upon discovery.
